user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of the Standard Library function memcmp (or other string-comparison functions such as strcmp/strncmp) is present in the provided code. The function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl performs only enum/int comparisons on Mode and an integer-based lookup via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, and it calls shutdown on a file descriptor. The related definitions show integer fields and enums; OS_ObjectIndexFromToken accesses token->obj_idx (no string operations). Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that compare null-terminated strings with memcmp and nothing needs to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in this snippet.
